instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-0152: What is 820-0152? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.ISL9239: What is ISL9239? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2016-2018 responsible for charging the battery and creating the power rail PPBUS_G3H.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.ISL9240: What is ISL9240? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2018 through 2020.
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0152</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Fixed <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> with replacing chip C03215 then no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi,

I'm new to the T2 chip Macs. I had a water damage come in and had 5v on the charger.  Got <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> working by replacing chips C03215. I was then getting 19.8V on the charger. I was only getting 1.8V on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> though. I was looking for something similiar to <CHIP>ISL9239</CHIP> like on Macbook Pro's but the only thing I found was a chip that looked like it was creating <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. This was <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. (i could be totally wrong) So I thought I'd reflow <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and after I was getting 12.4v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. Then after 30 seconds the charger went down to 5v again. And my <SIGNAL>PPBUS_GH</SIGNAL> went down to 1.7v. One thing that is bothering me is that <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> will "tone" short to ground for a few seconds then it won't. Could this be a chip failure. Is that something that happens? Like a chip will short and then it won't so it "tone"s short to ground and then doesn't?

I'm wondering where to look next. What makes <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> on this board? What makes <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and I'd like to figure out the order of what comes first. I see a couple of videos by Louis but they are for the MBP. Thank you for any direction. Right now I'm back at 5v on charger again.

[B]Recap:[/B]

[U][B]Started at:[/B][/U]

5v on charger
0v <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>

[U][B]Replaced C03215 chip:[/B][/U]

19.7v on charger
3.4v on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
1.7 on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>

[U][B]Reflowed U700(0?):[/B][/U]

19.8v on charger
3.4v on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>
12.7 on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>

[U][B]then it took a shit. LOL[/B][/U]

5v on charger
0 on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0152</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Fixed <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> with replacing chip C03215 then no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"One thing that is bothering me is that <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> will "tone" short to ground for a few seconds then it won'"
Allow always 10-15s before diode mode readings (or ohm scale) after power is removed.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is controlled by <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> (<CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP>).
It also send enable signal to <CHIP>U6960</CHIP>, which generates <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>.

You probably have bad solders under <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>, or still corrosion somewhere.
Compare diode mode readings on power rails between <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0152</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Fixed <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> with replacing chip C03215 then no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Thank you.  There really wasn't too much water damage and it was localized.  After replacing <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> (both) I was able to get 19.8v.  But <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> was at 1.7v.  Then I reflowed <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and it got me <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> for about 30 seconds.  Please verify my thinking. If <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> (<CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP>) is bad then I think that <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6960</CHIP> will not enable and not give me PPBUS or 3V3.  So maybe next time I'll look at <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> first. 

For diode and ohm I do wait awhile after powering down before testing. One weird thing is for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> when I test the same CAP but switch sides (positive/negative) with my probes it will "tone" every time I switch.  Wonder what that's all about?  Thx for the advice!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0152</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Fixed <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> with replacing chip C03215 then no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Is <CHIP>ISL9249</CHIP> and ISL9240HI the same?  Can I purchase the <CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP> on the Rossmann shop?  I didn't see it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0152</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Fixed <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> with replacing chip C03215 then no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
If you got reaction after reflow a chip, reball it at least.
No idea yet if <CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP> has firmware; I'll be surpised if not.

Please write new post instead of a comment.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0152</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Fixed <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> with replacing chip C03215 then no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Thx [USER="682"]2informaticos[/USER] just to be clear your saying that I can replace this <CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP> with an <CHIP>ISL9249</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0152</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Fixed <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> with replacing chip C03215 then no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Nope has to be <CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP>. <CHIP>ISL9249</CHIP> will not work.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0152</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Fixed <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> with replacing chip C03215 then no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Ok thats what I thought just was hoping I could find that chip but I can't.  Do you know where to get one?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-0152</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-02 Fixed <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> with replacing chip C03215 then no <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Good luck is my answer lol. Donor board if you can somehow find one or the AirPods wireless charger case has it on the circuit board. It?s like a 100 dollar case
